papers.title: Atmospheric characterization of HIP 67522 b with VLT/CRIRES+. VLT/CRIRES+ suggests a heavier planet and hints at deuterium fractionation
papers.abstract: Young transiting exoplanets provide unique opportunities to probe planetary atmospheres during the critical early phases of evolution. HIP 67522 b, a 17 Myr old hot Jupiter with an extraordinarily low bulk density, represents an ideal target for high-resolution transmission spectroscopy. We aim to characterize the atmospheric composition, thermal structure, and dynamics of HIP 67522 b using ground-based high-resolution near-infrared spectroscopy. We obtained high-resolution spectra with VLT/CRIRES+ in the K2166 band during a transit on 30 January 2025. We applied cross-correlation techniques and Bayesian nested sampling retrievals to constrain molecular abundances, temperature structure, and atmospheric dynamics. We detect H‚ÇÇO at 20œÉ and CO at 5œÉ, confirming the extremely extended atmosphere of this low-mass giant. A velocity offset of -2.9 ¬± 0.2 km s‚Åª¬π indicates day-to-night winds. The rotation velocity is constrained to <1.8 km s‚Åª¬π at 3œÉ, consistent with tidal locking. Retrieval analysis suggests a planetary mass of 29.8 ¬± 3 Earth masses and a vertically isothermal atmosphere. This mass is two times larger than the mass estimated from JWST atmospheric observations and inconsistent at 3œÉ hence leaving a doubt on the actual planetary density of the planet. Using the mass derived derived from the CRIRES+ data, we derive a C/O ratio of 0.83 ¬± 0.09, about 1.5 times solar, and a subsolar metallicity [C+O/H] = -0.8 ¬± 0.4 which can be increased if the atmosphere is cloudy, a degeneracy our data alone cannot resolve. We report a tentative 2œÉ detection of HDO with an extreme enrichment factor of 1000 relative to the protosolar D/H ratio. If confirmed, this would be the first detection of deuterium in an exoplanet atmosphere and would require intense escape rate to be explained.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine catching a planet in its cosmic infancy‚Äîthat's exactly what astronomers have done with HIP 67522 b, a "baby" Jupiter that's only 17 million years old. In cosmic terms, this planet is practically a newborn, giving scientists a rare window into how giant planets evolve during their most dramatic early years. What makes this discovery especially intriguing is that this young world appears to be a cosmic oddball: it's incredibly puffy, with a density so low it would float on water like a beach ball. Understanding planets like this helps us piece together the story of how planetary systems‚Äîincluding our own‚Äîformed and changed over billions of years.

**What They Did**

The research team used the Very Large Telescope in Chile, equipped with an ultra-sensitive instrument called CRIRES+, to analyze starlight filtering through the planet's atmosphere as it passed in front of its host star. Think of it like studying a shadow puppet show‚Äîas the planet blocks some of the star's light, different molecules in its atmosphere absorb specific colors, creating a unique fingerprint. The astronomers collected this light and broke it down into its component colors with incredible precision, then used computer models to decode what those patterns reveal about the planet's atmospheric makeup, temperature, and even its winds.

**Key Findings**

The team made several groundbreaking discoveries. They detected water vapor with extraordinary confidence and found carbon monoxide as well, confirming this planet has an extremely extended, puffy atmosphere. Surprisingly, their analysis suggests the planet is actually twice as heavy as previously thought‚Äîabout 30 times Earth's mass instead of 15. They discovered winds blowing at nearly 3 kilometers per second from the planet's day side to its night side. Most remarkably, they found tentative evidence of "heavy water" containing deuterium, which would be the first time this has been detected in any exoplanet atmosphere.

**Looking Forward**

This research opens exciting new frontiers in exoplanet science. The possible deuterium detection, if confirmed, could revolutionize our understanding of how planets lose their atmospheres over time. The conflicting mass measurements highlight how much we still have to learn about these distant worlds, promising that future observations will continue surprising us and reshaping our cosmic perspective.

papers.title: The ESO SupJup Survey IX: Isotopic evidence of a recent formation for Luhman 16AB
papers.abstract: The distinct formation pathways of directly-imaged exoplanets and isolated brown dwarfs might leave imprints in the inherited elemental and isotopic abundances, but such measurements require careful characterisation of the atmospheres. In particular, L-T transition objects exhibit signs of dynamics that drive their atmospheres out of chemical equilibrium. In this work, we studied the nearest L-T brown dwarfs, Luhman 16A and B, to assess the chemical dis-equilibrium in their atmospheres and to investigate their elemental and isotopic composition. As part of the ESO SupJup Survey, we obtained high-resolution CRIRES^+ K-band spectra of the binary, which were analysed using an atmospheric retrieval framework. We detect and retrieve the abundances of ¬π¬≤CO, H‚ÇÇO, CH‚ÇÑ, NH‚ÇÉ, H‚ÇÇS, HF, and the ¬π¬≥CO isotopologue. Both atmospheres are in chemical dis-equilibrium with somewhat stronger vertical mixing in Luhman 16A compared to B (K_zz,A 10‚Å∏.‚Å∑, K_zz,B 10‚Å∏.¬≤\ cm¬≤\ s‚Åª¬π). The tested chemical models, free- and dis-equilibrium chemistry, yield consistent mixing ratios and agree with earlier work at shorter wavelengths. The gaseous C/O ratios show evidence of oxygen trapping in silicate-oxide clouds. While the C/O ratios are consistent with solar, the metallicities are modestly enhanced with [C/H] 0.15. The carbon isotope ratios are measured at ¬π¬≤C/¬π¬≥C_A=74‚Å∫¬≤‚Çã‚ÇÇ and ¬π¬≤C/¬π¬≥C_B=74‚Å∫¬≥‚Çã‚ÇÉ. The coincident constraints of metallicities and isotopes across the binary reinforce their likely shared formation. The ¬π¬≤C/¬π¬≥C ratios are aligned with the present-day interstellar medium, but lower than the solar-system value. This suggests a recent inheritance and corroborates the relatively young age ( 500 Myr) of Luhman 16AB as members of the Oceanus moving group.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to solve a cosmic mystery: How do you tell the difference between a massive planet that formed around a star versus a "failed star" called a brown dwarf that formed on its own in space? Scientists have discovered they can act like stellar detectives, analyzing the chemical fingerprints in these objects' atmospheres to reveal their origin stories. This matters because understanding how planets and brown dwarfs form helps us piece together how solar systems‚Äîincluding our own‚Äîcome to be. By studying the nearest brown dwarfs to Earth, researchers are developing techniques that could eventually help us understand the formation of giant planets around other stars.

**What They Did**

The research team focused on Luhman 16A and B, a pair of brown dwarfs that are our closest neighbors of their kind, located just 6.5 light-years away. Using a powerful telescope in Chile equipped with specialized instruments, they collected incredibly detailed rainbow-like spectra of light from these objects. Think of it like analyzing the unique "barcode" of light that each object produces‚Äîdifferent molecules in their atmospheres absorb specific colors, creating distinct patterns. The scientists then used computer models to decode these light patterns, much like translating a foreign language, to determine what gases are present and in what amounts. They paid special attention to different versions of carbon molecules, called isotopes, which act like cosmic timestamps revealing when and where these objects formed.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that both brown dwarfs have atmospheres churning with chemical activity, like giant atmospheric washing machines mixing gases up and down. Most significantly, they measured the ratio of two carbon types and found it matches what we see in space today‚Äîbut differs from our solar system's 4.6-billion-year-old signature. The carbon ratio suggests these brown dwarfs formed relatively recently in cosmic terms, around 500 million years ago, when the galaxy had a different chemical composition. Both objects show nearly identical chemical fingerprints, confirming they formed together as a pair and share the same cosmic heritage.

**Looking Forward**

This research demonstrates that atmospheric chemistry can serve as a cosmic birth certificate, revealing not just how old celestial objects are, but when they formed relative to our solar system's history. As telescopes become more powerful, scientists will apply these techniques to study giant planets orbiting other stars, helping us understand whether planets like Jupiter are common or rare in the universe.

papers.title: Visual inspection of potential exocomet transits identified through machine learning and statistical methods
papers.abstract: In this work, we explore several ways to detect possible exocomet transits in the TESS (The Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite) light curves. The first one has been presented in our previous work, a machine learning approach based on the Random Forest algorithm. It was trained on asymmetric transit profiles calculated as a result of the modelling of a comet transit, and then applied to real star light curves from Sector 1 of TESS. This allowed us to detect 32 candidates with weak and non-periodic brightness dips that may correspond to comet-like events. The aim of this work is to analyse the events identified by the visual inspection to make sure that the features detected were not caused by instrumental effects. The second approach to detect possible exocomet transits, which is proposed, is an independent statistical method to test the results of the machine learning algorithm and to look for asymmetric minima directly in the light curves. This approach was applied to eta Pictoris light curves using TESS data from Sectors 5, 6, 32, and 33. The algorithm reproduced nearly all previously known events deeper than 0.03 % of the star flux, showing that it is efficient to detect shallow and irregular flux changes in the different sectors of the TESS data and at the different levels of noise. The combination of machine learning, visual inspection, and statistical analysis facilitates the identification of faint and short-lived asymmetric transits in photometric data. Although the number of confirmed exocomet transits is still small, the growing amount of observations points to their likely presence in many young planetary systems.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

While astronomers have discovered thousands of planets orbiting distant stars, we know much less about the smaller objects in these alien solar systems‚Äîlike comets. These icy wanderers are fascinating because they're leftovers from planetary formation, essentially fossils that can tell us how solar systems are born and evolve. Finding comets around other stars (called "exocomets") is incredibly difficult because they're tiny and unpredictable, but they could hold crucial clues about whether other planetary systems formed like ours did. Understanding exocomets also helps us learn about the chaotic early days of solar systems, when comets bombarded young planets and possibly delivered water and organic compounds necessary for life.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a clever detective system to spot exocomets using NASA's planet-hunting satellite TESS. Just like how a planet can briefly dim a star's light when it passes in front of it, a comet creates a similar but distinctive signature‚Äîan asymmetric dip that looks different from the symmetric dimming caused by planets. Think of it like the difference between a round ball's shadow versus an irregular cloud's shadow passing across a flashlight. The team trained a computer algorithm called Random Forest (like teaching a very fast pattern-recognition system) to identify these comet-like signatures in the brightness measurements of thousands of stars. They also used statistical methods to double-check their findings and employed human eyes to carefully inspect each candidate to rule out false alarms from instrument glitches.

**Key Findings**

The machine learning system identified 32 potential exocomet candidates from their initial survey, showing weak and irregular dimming events that match what astronomers expect from comet transits. When they tested their method on a star called eta Pictoris‚Äîalready known to host exocomets‚Äîtheir algorithm successfully detected nearly all previously known comet events that caused the star's brightness to drop by more than 0.03%. This success rate demonstrates that their detection system works effectively even for incredibly faint signals that would be nearly impossible to spot by eye alone.

**Looking Forward**

This research represents a major step toward systematically discovering exocomets throughout our galaxy. As more space telescopes collect data and these detection methods improve, astronomers expect to find exocomets in many young planetary systems. This could revolutionize our understanding of how solar systems evolve and help answer fundamental questions about whether the chaotic, comet-filled early history of our own solar system is typical or unusual in the universe.

papers.title: Imaging Venus-like Worlds: Spectral, Polarimetric, and UV Diagnostics for the Habitable Worlds Observatory
papers.abstract: Understanding planetary habitability requires a comparative approach that explores the divergent evolutionary outcomes of Earth and Venus. The Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO) will be uniquely positioned to conduct a statistical and physical census of terrestrial exoplanets spanning the Venus Zone (VZ) and the Habitable Zone (HZ), enabling the detection and atmospheric characterization of post-runaway greenhouse worlds (``exoVenuses''). We present an updated list of VZ exoplanets, which raises the number of known candidates to 370. We describe a science case and an observing strategy for VZ exoplanets that integrates precursor exoplanet detection data and stellar characterization with HWO direct imaging, spectroscopy across the UV/optical/IR, and spectropolarimetry. Our proposed framework emphasizes a pathway toward the diagnosis of sulfur chemistry (SO‚ÇÇ) and aerosol physics (H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ clouds/hazes), planetary redox states (O‚ÇÇ/O‚ÇÉ false positives from hydrogen loss), and cloud microphysics detection (rainbow polarization). We quantify implications for HWO requirements, including UV access to 0.2--0.4 Œºm, optical/NIR coverage to 1.5 Œºm, inner working angle (IWA) reaching 0.3--1.5 AU around nearby Sun-like stars, and the SNR/resolution needed for key features. Finally, we outline a community-driven path to producing robust demographic inferences and target selection for optimizing HWO observations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine if Earth had turned out like Venus‚Äîa scorching hellscape with crushing atmospheric pressure and clouds made of sulfuric acid. This isn't just science fiction; it's a real possibility that almost happened to our own planet. By studying "exoVenuses"‚ÄîVenus-like planets orbiting other stars‚Äîscientists can unlock the secrets of why some worlds become paradise while others become purgatory. This research is crucial for understanding what makes a planet truly habitable and could help us identify which of the thousands of discovered exoplanets might actually support life.

**What They Did**

The researchers created a comprehensive plan for studying Venus-like exoplanets using NASA's upcoming Habitable Worlds Observatory, a powerful space telescope designed to directly image planets around other stars. Think of it like having a super-advanced camera that can not only take pictures of distant worlds but also analyze their atmospheres by splitting their light into a rainbow of colors, much like a prism. The team compiled a catalog of 370 known Venus-zone planets‚Äîworlds that orbit close enough to their stars to potentially experience the same runaway greenhouse effect that turned Venus into an oven. They outlined specific techniques to detect telltale signs of Venus-like conditions, including sulfur compounds and sulfuric acid clouds.

**Key Findings**

The study identified 370 potential Venus-like worlds that could be studied with the new observatory‚Äînearly doubling previous estimates. The researchers determined exactly what the telescope needs to accomplish this ambitious survey: it must be able to detect ultraviolet light and distinguish planets that are extremely close to their stars, sometimes just one-third the distance between Earth and the Sun. They also identified specific chemical signatures that would reveal whether a planet has gone down Venus's apocalyptic path.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides a roadmap for one of the most important questions in astronomy: what determines a planet's fate? By studying both failed worlds like exoVenuses and potentially habitable ones, scientists will finally understand the delicate balance that keeps Earth livable, helping us better assess which distant worlds might harbor life.

papers.title: Ultra-hot Jupiter atmospheres at high spectral resolution
papers.abstract: Observations of ultra-hot Jupiters offer an unprecedented opportunity to study the physics of some of the most extreme planetary atmospheres known. With exceedingly high amounts of irradiation blasting their upper atmospheres, ultra-hot Jupiters have dayside temperatures comparable to some late type stars enabling refractory metals otherwise condensed in colder planets to exist in the gas phase, all the while still maintaining comparatively cool nightsides. The ensuing intense temperature contrasts can give rise not only to strong day-to-night winds, but also to vastly different chemical and cloud properties on opposing hemispheres. With its ability to resolve spectral features that are unique to individual chemical species, high resolution spectroscopy can unambiguously disentangle atmospheric signals of exoplanetary origin, which follow a well-defined Keplerian motion, from stationary or pseudo-stationary telluric and stellar lines. Combined, the high temperature of ultra-hot Jupiters providing access to refractory metals with narrow spectral features and the ability of high-resolution spectroscopy to resolve said narrow lines provides access to a wealth of information about these atmospheres that would otherwise be unavailable at lower resolving powers or for other types of planets. In this chapter we explore some of the key physical and chemical transitions that differentiate ultra-hot Jupiters from their colder counterparts and highlight the unique opportunities arising from probing their atmospheres using high resolution spectroscopy.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine planets so scorching hot that metals literally float through their skies like clouds. These alien worlds, called ultra-hot Jupiters, are some of the most extreme places in the universe‚Äîand they're teaching us incredible things about how planets can form and survive in conditions that would instantly vaporize anything we know on Earth. By studying these cosmic furnaces, scientists are pushing the boundaries of what we thought was possible for planetary atmospheres, while developing techniques that will eventually help us analyze more Earth-like worlds and perhaps even detect signs of life elsewhere in the galaxy.

**What They Did**

The researchers used a sophisticated technique called high-resolution spectroscopy‚Äîessentially a super-powered method of analyzing light. Think of it like using a prism to split sunlight into a rainbow, but far more precise. When starlight passes through an exoplanet's atmosphere, different chemicals absorb specific colors of light, creating a unique "fingerprint." The challenge is separating these faint planetary signals from much brighter interference from Earth's atmosphere and the host star. The key breakthrough is that planets orbit their stars, so their chemical signatures shift slightly in wavelength due to their motion‚Äîlike how an ambulance siren changes pitch as it moves toward or away from you. This allows scientists to isolate the planetary signals with remarkable precision.

**Key Findings**

Ultra-hot Jupiters are truly alien worlds where familiar rules break down. Their dayside temperatures reach 2,000-3,000¬∞C‚Äîhot enough to melt copper‚Äîwhile their nightsides remain relatively cool. This extreme temperature difference creates powerful winds and completely different atmospheric chemistry on each hemisphere. Most remarkably, metals that would normally form solid particles or clouds in cooler planets instead exist as gases in these furnaces, floating freely through the atmosphere and creating detectable signatures that reveal the planet's composition and weather patterns.

**Looking Forward**

These extreme laboratories are perfect testing grounds for atmospheric analysis techniques that will eventually be applied to potentially habitable planets. As we refine our ability to detect and analyze atmospheric gases on ultra-hot Jupiters, we're developing the tools needed to search for water vapor, oxygen, and other biosignatures on Earth-like exoplanets‚Äîbringing us closer to answering whether we're alone in the universe.

papers.title: Probing Atmospheric Escape Through the Near-Infrared Helium Triplet
papers.abstract: The most productive tracer of exoplanetary atmospheric escape is the measurement of excess absorption in the near-infrared metastable helium triplet during transits. Atmospheric escape of a close-in planet's atmosphere plays a role in its evolutionary pathway, but to which extent remains unknown. It could explain demographic features like the radius valley and Neptunian desert. We will describe the development of instrumental, reduction, and modelling techniques to study exoplanetary atmospheric escape, focusing on the helium triplet. One such development is the NIGHT spectrograph, intended to provide the first survey of escaping atmospheres. NIGHT spectra will be processed with ANTARESS, a state-of-the-art workflow for reducing high-resolution spectral time-series of exoplanet transits and computing transmission spectra in a robust and reproducible way. Transmission spectra contain the potential signature of the planetary atmosphere as well as distortions induced by the occultation of local regions of the stellar surface along the transit chord. Transmission spectra cannot be corrected for those stellar distortions without biasing the planetary signal. They must instead be directly interpreted using a numerical model like the EvE code, which generates realistic stellar spectra that account for the system's 3D architecture, the planet's atmospheric structure, and its local occultation of the stellar disc. This global approach, from the measurement and computation of transmission spectra to their interpretation, will be a legacy of the NCCR PlanetS, becoming the standard procedure to study high-resolution spectroscopy of planetary transits.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine planets slowly bleeding their atmospheres into space‚Äîthis isn't science fiction, but reality for many worlds orbiting close to their stars. Scientists have discovered that some exoplanets are literally losing their air, and this process might explain major mysteries in our cosmic neighborhood. Why do we see so few medium-sized planets? Why are certain regions around stars seemingly empty of Neptune-like worlds? The answers may lie in atmospheric escape‚Äîa process that could reshape entire planetary populations over millions of years. Understanding how planets lose their atmospheres helps us piece together the life stories of worlds beyond our solar system and reveals why planetary systems look the way they do.

**What They Did**

Researchers developed sophisticated new tools to catch planets in the act of losing their atmospheres. They focus on helium‚Äîa lightweight gas that glows with a distinct infrared signature when heated by starlight. Think of it like a cosmic fingerprint that becomes visible when a planet's atmosphere is being stripped away. The team created a new instrument called NIGHT specifically designed to survey escaping atmospheres across many different planets. They also developed advanced computer software called ANTARESS to process the incredibly faint signals captured during planetary transits‚Äîthose brief moments when planets pass in front of their stars. The challenge is enormous: scientists must separate the tiny atmospheric signals from the much brighter stellar background, like trying to detect a whisper during a thunderstorm.

**Key Findings**

While this paper focuses on developing methods rather than reporting specific discoveries, the helium detection technique has already proven remarkably successful. The near-infrared helium signal provides the most reliable way to spot escaping atmospheres, acting like a cosmic smoke detector for planetary air loss. The researchers created sophisticated computer models that can distinguish between signals from the planet's atmosphere and confusing effects from the star's surface‚Äîa crucial breakthrough that makes reliable measurements possible.

**Looking Forward**

These new tools promise to revolutionize our understanding of planetary evolution. The NIGHT survey will create the first comprehensive census of atmospheric escape, potentially revealing which types of planets are most vulnerable to losing their air. This research could finally explain the mysterious gaps in planetary populations and help us understand whether Earth-like worlds can maintain their atmospheres around different types of stars‚Äîcrucial knowledge for the search for life beyond our solar system.

papers.title: Unraveling the Brown Dwarf Desert: Four New Discoveries and a Unifying, Period-Coded Picture
papers.abstract: We present four newly validated transiting brown dwarfs identified through TESS photometry and confirmed with high-precision radial velocity measurements obtained from the FEROS and PLATOSpec spectrographs. Notably, three of these companions exhibit orbital periods exceeding 100 days, thereby expanding the sample of long-period transiting brown dwarfs from two to five systems. The host stars of long-period brown dwarfs show mild subsolar metallicity. These discoveries highlight the expansion of the metal-poor, long-period distribution and help us better understand the brown dwarf desert. In our comparative analysis of eccentricity and metallicity demographics, we utilize catalogues of long-period giant planets, brown dwarfs, and low-mass stellar companions. After accounting for tidal influences, the eccentricity distribution aligns with that of low-mass stellar binaries, presenting a different profile than that observed within the giant planet population. Additionally, the metallicity of the host stars reveals a noteworthy trend: short-period transiting brown dwarfs are predominantly associated with metal-rich stars, whereas long-period brown dwarfs are more often found around metal-poor stars, demonstrating statistical similarities to low-mass stellar hosts. This trend has also been previously observed in studies of hot and cold Jupiters and points to a period-coded mixture of channels. A natural explanation is that most brown dwarfs originate from fragmentation at wider separations, with long-period systems retaining this stellar-like imprint, while only those embedded in massive, long-lived, metal-rich protoplanetary discs are efficiently delivered and stabilised to short orbits.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to solve a cosmic mystery: why are brown dwarfs‚Äîobjects too big to be planets but too small to be stars‚Äîso rare around other stars? This puzzle, known as the "brown dwarf desert," has intrigued astronomers for decades. These cosmic oddities are like failed stars that never quite ignited, sitting in a middle ground between giant planets and true stars. Understanding where they come from and why they're so scarce helps us piece together how planetary systems like our own solar system form and evolve. This research doesn't just catalog new discoveries‚Äîit reveals fundamental patterns about how different types of companions end up orbiting stars.

**What They Did**

The research team used NASA's planet-hunting telescope called TESS (Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite) to spot four new brown dwarfs by watching for tiny dips in starlight as these objects crossed in front of their host stars. Think of it like watching a moth fly in front of a streetlight‚Äîthe light dims briefly as the moth passes by. To confirm these discoveries, the scientists used powerful ground-based telescopes to measure how the host stars wobble slightly due to the gravitational tug of their brown dwarf companions. They then compared their findings with existing catalogs of giant planets, brown dwarfs, and small stars to look for broader patterns in how these different types of companions behave.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered four new brown dwarfs, with three taking more than 100 days to complete their orbits‚Äîrelatively leisurely compared to many known exoplanets. This discovery more than doubled the number of known long-period brown dwarfs from two to five systems. Most surprisingly, they uncovered a clear pattern: brown dwarfs with short, quick orbits tend to circle metal-rich stars (those with lots of heavy elements), while those with longer orbits prefer metal-poor stars. The researchers also found that brown dwarfs behave more like small stars than giant planets when it comes to their orbital shapes and the types of stars they orbit.

**Looking Forward**

These discoveries suggest that brown dwarfs form through two different pathways, like taking different routes to the same destination. Long-period brown dwarfs likely formed far from their stars through a process similar to how binary star systems form, while short-period ones may have started life in the thick, metal-rich disks of material that also birth giant planets. This research helps astronomers better understand the diverse family tree of objects that can orbit stars, ultimately improving our knowledge of how solar systems form and providing context for our own cosmic neighborhood.

papers.title: Observational imprints of tidal internal gravity wave dissipation in star-planet systems
papers.abstract: Tidal interactions play a crucial role in the orbital evolution of close-in star-planet systems. There are numerous manifestations of tides, including planetary orbital migration, breaking resonant chains, tidal heating, orbital circularization, spin-orbit alignment, and stellar and planetary spin synchronization. In the present study, we focus on the dissipation of internal gravity waves within stars. We examine two mechanisms: wave breaking in stars with radiative cores and magnetic wave conversion in stars with convective cores. Applying tidal prescriptions modelling these processes, we demonstrate that the enhanced stellar rotation of both TOI-2458 and GJ 504 can be explained by the previous engulfment of a hot Jupiter caused by gravity wave damping. Furthermore, we show that the observed population of hot Jupiters can be divided into two distinct subsamples: those that are too young for gravity wave dissipation and those where it is ongoing. These subsamples exhibit qualitatively different orbital period distributions: young systems have a uniform distribution, while older systems show a steep decline at short orbital periods. Using a population synthesis approach, we successfully reproduce the main features of the older hot Jupiter sample based on the distribution of the younger systems. According to our estimates, up to 20% of the main-sequence stars within the mass range [0.7,1.5] M‚òâ that once hosted a hot Jupiter may have since engulfed it. Our results highlight the key role of internal gravity wave dissipation in shaping the orbital architectures of hot Jupiter systems.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Hot Jupiters‚Äîgiant planets that orbit extremely close to their stars‚Äîhave puzzled astronomers since their discovery. These worlds complete an orbit in just days, enduring temperatures that would vaporize metal. But here's the mystery: they shouldn't stay there forever. New research reveals that many of these planets are actually spiraling into their stars and getting devoured, fundamentally changing how we understand planetary system evolution. This cosmic dance between stars and planets helps explain why we see certain patterns in exoplanet populations and suggests that many stars may be hiding evidence of consumed worlds.

**What They Did**

The researchers studied how invisible waves within stars can doom nearby planets. When a hot Jupiter orbits close to its star, it creates internal waves‚Äîlike ripples in a pond‚Äîthat travel through the star's interior. These waves eventually break apart or get absorbed, which steals energy from the planet's orbit. Think of it like friction gradually slowing down a spinning top. The team used computer models to simulate this process across thousands of star-planet systems, then compared their predictions to real observations of known hot Jupiter systems and rapidly spinning stars.

**Key Findings**

The evidence points to widespread planetary cannibalism. The researchers found that up to 20% of sun-like stars may have already swallowed a hot Jupiter during their lifetime. They discovered that hot Jupiter populations split into two distinct groups: young systems where planets haven't had time to spiral inward, and older systems where many planets have already been consumed. The smoking gun comes from certain fast-spinning stars that likely gained their rotation from gobbling up planets, including specific examples like TOI-2458 and GJ 504.

**Looking Forward**

This research transforms our understanding of planetary system evolution from a static picture to a dynamic one where planets regularly meet fiery ends. It suggests that hot Jupiters represent survivors in a cosmic elimination game, with many of their siblings already lost to stellar appetites. Future telescopes may help us identify more "guilty" stars that bear the rotational signatures of their planetary meals.

papers.title: Architectures of Planetary Systems II: Trends with Host Star Mass and Metallicity
papers.abstract: The current census of planetary systems displays a wide range of architectures. Extending earlier work, this paper investigates the correlation between our classification framework for these architectures and host stellar properties. Specifically, we explore how planetary system properties depend on stellar mass and stellar metallicity. This work confirms previously detected trends that jovian planets are less prevalent for low-mass and low-metallicity stars. We also find new, but expected trends such as that the total mass in planets increases with stellar mass, and that observed planetary system masses show an upper limit that is roughly consistent with expectations from the stability of circumstellar disks. We tentatively identify potential unique trends in the host stars of super-puffs and hot jupiters and a possible subdivision of the class of hot jupiter systems. In general, we find that system architectures are not overly dependent on host star properties.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand why neighborhoods look different across a city‚Äîsome have mansions, others have apartments, and many have a mix of housing types. Astronomers face a similar puzzle when studying planetary systems beyond our solar system. With over 5,000 confirmed exoplanets discovered, we see an amazing variety: some systems pack multiple planets closer to their star than Mercury is to our Sun, while others host lonely giant planets in distant orbits. Understanding what shapes these cosmic neighborhoods helps us figure out how planetary systems form and whether Earth-like worlds are common or rare in our galaxy.

**What They Did**

The research team analyzed data from hundreds of known planetary systems, acting like cosmic census takers. They looked for patterns by comparing two key properties of the host stars: their mass (how heavy they are compared to our Sun) and their metallicity (how much of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium they contain). Think of metallicity as the star's "recipe"‚Äîstars with more heavy elements are considered metal-rich. The astronomers then examined how these stellar properties relate to the types of planets orbiting around them, much like urban planners studying how neighborhood characteristics influence housing development.

**Key Findings**

The study confirmed that massive Jupiter-like planets strongly prefer metal-rich, heavier stars as hosts‚Äîa trend astronomers had suspected. More surprisingly, they discovered that more massive stars tend to have planetary systems with greater total mass, suggesting bigger stars can support more substantial planetary families. The researchers also found that there appears to be an upper limit to how massive planetary systems can become, which matches theoretical predictions about disk stability. They identified intriguing hints that ultra-low-density "super-puff" planets and close-orbiting hot Jupiters might prefer specific types of host stars.

**Looking Forward**

These findings provide crucial clues for the next generation of planet hunters. By understanding which stars are most likely to host different types of planets, astronomers can better target their searches for Earth-like worlds and optimize precious telescope time, bringing us closer to answering whether we're alone in the universe.

papers.title: The asymmetric structure of the inner disc around HD 142527 A with VLTI/MATISSE
papers.abstract: Circumstellar discs, and especially their inner regions, covering ranges from <1 au to a few astronomical units, are the birthplaces of terrestrial planets. The inner regions are thought to be similarly diverse in structure as the well-observed outer regions probed by ALMA. Combining data and results from previous studies of the VLTI/PIONIER and VLTI/GRAVITY instruments with new, multi-epoch VLTI/MATISSE observations, we aim to provide a comprehensive picture of the structure of the inner regions of the circumstellar disc around the F-type Herbig Ae/Be star HD 142527 A, the primary of a binary star system. We model the multi-wavelength interferometric data using a parametrised, geometrically thin disc model, allowing for azimuthal asymmetry, exploring a first-order disc modulation and an off-centre Gaussian component. We find time-variable structures in the N-band observables, which we reproduce with time-dependent models. This variability manifests as azimuthally asymmetric emission, evidenced by strong, non-zero closure phases in the N-band data. Fits to individual epochs of the N-band observations yield better œá¬≤_r values than fits to all epochs simultaneously. This suggests substantial changes in the geometry of the inner disc emission from 1 au up to a few astronomical-unit scales from one year to the next. Moreover, our models produce a very close-in inner disc rim R_rim‚âà0.1 au. All together, we find a very complex, substantially non-point symmetric and temporally-variable disc (r_out6 au) around the primary. The very close-in inner rim indicates the presence of material inside the typical wall-like sublimation radius R_rim,literature‚âà0.3 au. The complex, temporally variable inner-disc geometry is likely affected or even caused by the close passing ( 5 au) and short orbit (P‚âà24 yr) of the companion HD 142527 B.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand how Earth formed by studying our solar system today‚Äîyou'd miss the crucial early stages when planets were actually taking shape. That's the challenge astronomers face when studying planet formation around other stars. This research tackles that problem by peering into the cosmic nursery where Earth-like planets are born: the inner regions of dusty discs around young stars. Understanding these planet-forming environments helps us grasp not only how alien worlds come to be, but also the origin story of our own solar system. It's like having a time machine to witness planetary birth in action.

**What They Did**

The researchers studied HD 142527, a young star system about 450 light-years away, using powerful telescopes that work together like a giant magnifying glass. They combined multiple telescopes in Chile to create incredibly detailed images‚Äîa technique called interferometry that's like using several cameras simultaneously to capture fine details invisible to any single telescope. Over multiple years, they observed the star at different wavelengths of infrared light, which reveals the warm dust and gas swirling around the star. Think of it as taking thermal photographs that show heat signatures from the planet-forming material.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered a remarkably chaotic and dynamic disc around this young star. Most surprisingly, they found hot material extremely close to the star‚Äîjust 0.1 astronomical units away (about one-tenth the distance from Earth to our Sun). That's much closer than expected, like finding ice surviving next to a campfire. The disc showed dramatic changes from year to year, with lopsided, asymmetric structures constantly shifting. This turbulent behavior likely results from a companion star that swoops close every 24 years, gravitationally stirring up the planet-forming material like a cosmic egg beater.

**Looking Forward**

These findings suggest that planet formation might be far more chaotic and dynamic than previously thought. If similar disruption occurs in other young star systems, it could explain why we see such diverse types of exoplanets‚Äîfrom super-Earths to hot Jupiters in unusual orbits. This research provides a crucial piece of the puzzle for understanding how planetary systems evolve and why each one ends up so unique.

papers.title: ExoDNN: Boosting exoplanet detection with artificial intelligence. Application to Gaia Data Release 3
papers.abstract: We combine Gaia Data Release 3 and artificial intelligence to enhance the current statistics of substellar companions, particularly within regions of the orbital period vs. mass parameter space that remain poorly constrained by the radial velocity and transit detection methods. Using supervised learning, we train a deep neural network to recognise the characteristic distribution of the fit quality statistics corresponding to a Gaia DR3 astrometric solution for a non single star. We generate a deep learning model, ExoDNN, which predicts the probability of a DR3 source to host unresolved companions based on those fit quality statistics. Applying the predictive capability of ExoDNN to a volume limited sample of F,G,K and M stars from Gaia DR3, we have produced a list of 7414 candidate stars hosting companions. The stellar properties of these candidates, such as their mass and metallicity, are similar to those of the Gaia DR3 non single star sample. We also identify synergies with future observatories, such as PLATO, and we propose a follow up strategy with the intention of investigating the most promising candidates among those samples.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Finding planets beyond our solar system‚Äîcalled exoplanets‚Äîis one of astronomy's most exciting frontiers. These distant worlds could hold clues about how planetary systems form and whether life exists elsewhere in the universe. However, detecting exoplanets is incredibly challenging because they're tiny and dim compared to their host stars. It's like trying to spot a firefly next to a stadium floodlight from across the country. Current detection methods work well for certain types of planets but miss many others, leaving huge gaps in our cosmic census. This research represents a breakthrough in filling those gaps by using artificial intelligence to find hidden planetary companions.

**What They Did**

The researchers turned to data from Gaia, a European space telescope that has been precisely measuring the positions and movements of over a billion stars. When a star has an orbiting planet, the planet's gravity causes the star to wobble slightly‚Äîlike a person spinning while holding a heavy ball on a string. These tiny wobbles show up as subtle irregularities in Gaia's measurements. The team trained a deep neural network (a type of AI similar to what recognizes faces in photos) to spot the telltale patterns in measurement quality that indicate a star is being tugged around by an unseen companion. They called their AI system ExoDNN and fed it data from hundreds of thousands of stars to teach it what to look for.

**Key Findings**

ExoDNN identified 7,414 stars that likely host planetary or other substellar companions‚Äîa massive haul from a single analysis. These candidate systems have similar characteristics to already-confirmed multi-star systems, which gives confidence in the AI's predictions. Importantly, this method can detect types of planets that traditional techniques often miss, particularly those in longer orbits around their stars. The AI essentially created a new treasure map of potential exoplanet locations across our galaxy.

**Looking Forward**

Why It Matters

Finding planets beyond our solar system‚Äîcalled exoplanets‚Äîis one of astronomy's most exciting frontiers. These distant worlds could hold clues about how planetary systems form and whether life exists elsewhere in the universe. However, detecting exoplanets is incredibly challenging because they're tiny and dim compared to their host stars. It's like trying to spot a firefly next to a stadium floodlight from across the country. Current detection methods work well for certain types of planets but miss many others, leaving huge gaps in our cosmic census. This research represents a breakthrough in filling those gaps by using artificial intelligence to find hidden planetary companions.

What They Did

The researchers turned to data from Gaia, a European space telescope that has been precisely measuring the positions and movements of over a billion stars. When a star has an orbiting planet, the planet's gravity causes the star to wobble slightly‚Äîlike a person spinning while holding a heavy ball on a string. These tiny wobbles show up as subtle irregularities in Gaia's measurements. The team trained a deep neural network (a type of AI similar to what recognizes faces in photos) to spot the telltale patterns in measurement quality that indicate a star is being tugged around by an unseen companion. They called their AI system ExoDNN and fed it data from hundreds of thousands of stars to teach it what to look for.

Key Findings

ExoDNN identified 7,414 stars that likely host planetary or other substellar companions‚Äîa massive haul from a single analysis. These candidate systems have similar characteristics to already-confirmed multi-star systems, which gives confidence in the AI's predictions. Importantly, this method can detect types of planets that traditional techniques often miss, particularly those in longer orbits around their stars. The AI essentially created a new treasure map of potential exoplanet locations across our galaxy.

Looking Forward

This research demonstrates how artificial intelligence can revolutionize exoplanet hunting by finding needles in cosmic haystacks. The 7,414 candidates provide astronomers with prime targets for follow-up observations using ground-based telescopes and future space missions like PLATO. As AI techniques improve and more Gaia data becomes available, we can expect even more sophisticated planet-hunting algorithms that will dramatically expand our catalog of known worlds.
